Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Comprehensive Modeling Approach to Cognitively Diagnostic Assessment: Methodological Developments and Practical Implementations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project will develop an 8th grade assessment for proportional reasoning from a cognitive diagnosis model (CDM) framework. CDMs are psychometric models developed specifically for diagnosing the presence or absence of fine-grained skills or processes required in solving problems on a test. Assessments based on CDMs can provide information deemed more diagnostic and descriptive, therefore, more relevant in applied instructional settings. This project will also introduce a comprehensive framework that will make the construction, administration and analysis of such assessments more practicable. New models, methodologies, and a computer program will be developed in this project to facilitate wider applications of CDMs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For assessments to be truly formative, they need to provide diagnostic information that is finer-grained in nature. This necessitates the use of assessments that are explicitly developed to capture diagnostic information, and procedures capable of extracting this information. This projects aimed to satisfy these requirements by developing a proportional reasoning assessment for middle grade students from a diagnostic framework, and to use cognitive diagnosis models to analyze data from these assessments. The assessment development process involved rewriting some of the item writing and test construction rules to ensure that the test as a whole can provide information that differentiates individuals with varying skill mastery patterns. In addition, the cognitive diagnosis modeling component necessitated the development of new procedures and methodologies that are appropriate for analyzing diagnostic test data.

At the end of the project, a pool of about 450 proportional test items has been created. These items were cataloged in terms of the skills they measure, their expected difficulty level, and context in which the problems were being asked. A subset of 80 items have been administered to over 800 students. The data were analyzed using traditional item response theory and cognitive diagnosis models. Our results show that many students who received the same overall scores can have very different skill mastery profiles. This underscores the fact that proficiency groupings based on overall scores can be misleading, and students’ specific needs can be better addressed by examining the individual skill mastery and nonmastery patterns. Finally, several computer programs were also written to implement the new models and procedures developed in this project. These programs can be obtained from the PI free of charge.

 

Intellectual Merit: This project developed a proportional reasoning assessment that can provide diagnostic information more relevant to student learning and more useful in applied instructional settings. The test development process necessitated the participation of experts from various disciplines: mathematicians, mathematics education researchers, mathematics teachers, and psychometricians. This project also provides applied researchers with a computational tool that can encourage them to explore and expand the use of cognitive diagnosis in other domains of applications.

 

Broader Impact: This project illustrated the use of cognitive diagnosis modeling as an integrative framework for the construction and analysis of a diagnostic proportional reasoning assessment. The project can serve as a template for the development of diagnostic assessments in other STEM domains. The highly interpretable and learning-centered information derived from an interdisciplinary collaboration required by the framework can serve as a blueprint in mapping out timely, appropriate, and targeted interventions. To disseminate the findings, the project has produced 14 articles, 17 workshops, and over 50 presentations.
